Provides a tailored authentication experience with: - Bootstrap-compatible form styling - Standard Django authentication mechanism

class tracker.forms.HabitForm(data=None, files=None, auto_id='id_%s', prefix=None, initial=None, error_class=<class 'django.forms.utils.ErrorList'>, label_suffix=None, empty_permitted=False, instance=None, use_required_attribute=None, renderer=None)[source]

Bases: ModelForm

ModelForm for creating and editing Habit instances.

Provides a user-friendly interface for habit creation with: - Styled form fields - Validation based on Habit model constraints - Bootstrap-compatible form widgets

Managed Fields:

name (str): Name of the habit description (str, optional): Detailed description of the habit frequency (str): Frequency of habit performance difficulty (str): Subjective difficulty level of the habit

Widgets:

  • Text input for name with placeholder

  • Textarea for description

  • Select dropdowns for frequency and difficulty

class tracker.forms.ProgressLogForm(data=None, files=None, auto_id='id_%s', prefix=None, initial=None, error_class=<class 'django.forms.utils.ErrorList'>, label_suffix=None, empty_permitted=False, instance=None, use_required_attribute=None, renderer=None)[source]

Bases: ModelForm

ModelForm for logging progress of a specific habit.

Enables users to record detailed information about habit performance: - Status of habit completion - Optional notes - Optional time spent on the habit

Managed Fields:

status (str): Completion status (completed/skipped/missed) notes (str, optional): Additional context about habit performance duration_minutes (int, optional): Time invested in the habit

Widgets:

  • Select dropdown for status

  • Textarea for notes

  • Number input for duration

class tracker.forms.UserRegistrationForm(*args, **kwargs)[source]

Bases: UserCreationForm

Extended user registration form with enhanced validation and styling.

This form provides a customized user registration experience with: - Email uniqueness validation - Username and password length requirements - Bootstrap-compatible form styling

Fields:

email (EmailField): User’s email address with validation username (CharField): User’s desired username with length validation password1 (CharField): User’s password password2 (CharField): Password confirmation field

Validates:

  • Email uniqueness

  • Minimum username length (4 characters)

  • Django’s default password strength checks

tracker.models module

class tracker.models.Habit(*args, **kwargs)[source]

Bases: Model

Represents a habit that a user wants to track and maintain.

This model allows users to define and monitor their personal habits, including frequency, difficulty level, and tracking progress.

FREQUENCY_CHOICES

Predefined choices for habit tracking frequency.

Type:

list

DIFFICULTY_LEVELS

Predefined difficulty levels for habits.

Type:

list

user

The user who owns the habit.

Type:

ForeignKey

name

The name of the habit, with length constraints.

Type:

CharField

description

Additional details about the habit.

Type:

TextField, optional

frequency

How often the habit should be performed.

Type:

CharField

difficulty

Subjective difficulty level of the habit.

Type:

CharField

start_date

The date the user began tracking the habit.

Type:

DateField

is_active

Whether the habit is currently being tracked.

Type:

BooleanField

created_at

Timestamp of habit creation.

Type:

DateTimeField

updated_at

Timestamp of last update.

Type:

DateTimeField

Meta:

  • Ensures unique habit names per user

  • Orders habits by creation date (most recent first)

DIFFICULTY_LEVELS = [('easy', 'Easy'), ('medium', 'Medium'), ('hard', 'Hard')]
exception DoesNotExist

Bases: ObjectDoesNotExist

FREQUENCY_CHOICES = [('daily', 'Daily'), ('weekly', 'Weekly'), ('monthly', 'Monthly'), ('custom', 'Custom')]
exception MultipleObjectsReturned

Bases: MultipleObjectsReturned

calculate_completion_percentage(days=30)[source]

Calculate the percentage of habit completion for a given time period.

Parameters:

days (int, optional) – Number of days to calculate completion over. Defaults to 30 days.

Returns:

Percentage of habit completion (0-100).

Returns 0 if no logs exist in the specified period.

Return type:

float

Note

  • Considers only logs within the specified date range

  • Calculates based on completed vs. total logs

calculate_current_streak()[source]

Calculate the current consecutive days the habit has been completed.

This method examines the habit’s progress logs to determine the current streak by counting consecutive completed days from today backward.

Returns:

Number of consecutive days the habit has been completed.

Return type:

int

Note

  • Assumes completed logs are ordered from most recent to oldest

  • Stops counting streak when a non-consecutive day is encountered

objects = <django.db.models.manager.Manager object>
progress_set

Accessor to the related objects manager on the reverse side of a many-to-one relation.

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

Parent.children is a ReverseManyToOneDescriptor instance.

Most of the implementation is delegated to a dynamically defined manager class built by create_forward_many_to_many_manager() defined below.

start_date

A wrapper for a deferred-loading field. When the value is read from this object the first time, the query is executed.

updated_at

A wrapper for a deferred-loading field. When the value is read from this object the first time, the query is executed.

user

Accessor to the related object on the forward side of a many-to-one or one-to-one (via ForwardOneToOneDescriptor subclass) relation.

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

Child.parent is a ForwardManyToOneDescriptor instance.

class tracker.models.ProgressLog(*args, **kwargs)[source]

Bases: Model

Tracks daily progress for individual habits.

This model allows logging the status of a habit on a specific date, including completion status, optional notes, and time spent.

STATUS_CHOICES

Predefined status options for habit tracking.

Type:

list

habit

The habit being logged.

Type:

ForeignKey

date

The date of the log entry.

Type:

DateField

status

Current status of the habit (completed/skipped/missed).

Type:

CharField

notes

Additional comments about the habit performance.

Type:

TextField, optional

duration_minutes

Time spent on the habit.

Type:

PositiveIntegerField, optional

Meta:

  • Ensures unique log per habit per date

  • Orders logs by most recent date

exception DoesNotExist

Bases: ObjectDoesNotExist

exception MultipleObjectsReturned

Bases: MultipleObjectsReturned

A wrapper for a deferred-loading field. When the value is read from this object the first time, the query is executed.

Accessor to the related object on the forward side of a many-to-one or one-to-one (via ForwardOneToOneDescriptor subclass) relation.

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

Child.parent is a ForwardManyToOneDescriptor instance.

classmethod log_progress(habit, status, date=None, notes=None, duration=None)[source]

Convenience method to create or update a habit progress log.

This method allows easy logging of habit progress, either creating a new log or updating an existing one for a specific date.

Parameters:

  • habit (Habit) – The habit being logged.

  • status (str) – Status of the habit (completed/skipped/missed).

  • date (date, optional) – Date of the log. Defaults to current date.

  • notes (str, optional) – Additional notes about the habit performance.

  • duration (int, optional) – Time spent on the habit in minutes.

Returns:

The created or updated progress log instance.

Return type:

ProgressLog

Note

  • If a log for the given habit and date exists, it will be updated

  • If no log exists, a new one will be created

notes

A wrapper for a deferred-loading field. When the value is read from this object the first time, the query is executed.

objects = <django.db.models.manager.Manager object>
status

A wrapper for a deferred-loading field. When the value is read from this object the first time, the query is executed.

tracker.tests module

tracker.urls module

tracker.views module

tracker.views.create_habit(request)[source]

Provide a view for creating new habits.

This view allows authenticated users to create a new habit. For POST requests, it validates the habit form and saves a new Habit instance.

Parameters:

request (HttpRequest) – The HTTP request object.

Returns:

  • Renders ‘habit_form.html’ with habit creation form

  • Redirects to ‘dashboard’ upon successful habit creation

Return type:

HttpResponse

Requires:

  • User authentication

Behaviors:

  • Associates new habit with the current user

  • Displays success message on habit creation

tracker.views.dashboard_view(request)[source]

Render the user’s personal dashboard.

This view is only accessible to authenticated users. It retrieves and displays the user’s habits and recent progress logs.

Parameters:

request (HttpRequest) – The HTTP request object.

Returns:

Renders ‘authentication/dashboard.html’ with user’s habits

and recent progress logs.

Return type:

HttpResponse

Requires:

  • User authentication

Context Variables:

  • habits: QuerySet of Habit objects owned by the current user

  • recent_logs: Last 5 ProgressLog entries for the user’s habits

tracker.views.delete_habit(request, habit_id)[source]

Provide a view for deleting a specific habit.

This view allows authenticated users to delete one of their habits. It requires a POST request to confirm the deletion and ensures the habit belongs to the current user.

Parameters:

  • request (HttpRequest) – The HTTP request object.

  • habit_id (int) – The primary key of the habit to be deleted.

Returns:

  • Renders ‘habit_confirm_delete.html’ for confirmation

  • Redirects to ‘dashboard’ after successful deletion

Return type:

HttpResponse

Raises:

Http404 – If the habit does not exist or does not belong to the user

Requires:

  • User authentication

Behaviors:

  • Displays confirmation page on GET request

  • Deletes habit and redirects on POST request

  • Displays success message after deletion

tracker.views.edit_habit(request, habit_id)[source]

Provide a view for editing an existing habit.

This view allows authenticated users to modify details of a specific habit. It ensures the habit belongs to the current user.

Parameters:

  • request (HttpRequest) – The HTTP request object.

  • habit_id (int) – The primary key of the habit to be edited.

Returns:

  • Renders ‘habit_form.html’ with habit edit form

  • Redirects to ‘dashboard’ upon successful habit update

Return type:

HttpResponse

Raises:

Http404 – If the habit does not exist or does not belong to the user

Requires:

  • User authentication

Behaviors:

  • Populates form with existing habit details

  • Displays success message on habit update

tracker.views.home(request)[source]

Render the home page of the application.

This view serves as the landing page for the HabitFlow application. It is accessible to all users, including unauthenticated visitors.

Parameters:

request (HttpRequest) – The HTTP request object.

Returns:

Renders the ‘home.html’ template.

Return type:

HttpResponse

tracker.views.log_habit_progress(request, habit_id)[source]

Provide a view for logging progress on a specific habit.

This view allows authenticated users to log their progress for a particular habit. It supports creating new progress logs and updating existing logs for the same habit and date.

Parameters:

  • request (HttpRequest) – The HTTP request object.

  • habit_id (int) – The primary key of the habit to log progress for.

Returns:

  • Renders ‘progress_log_form.html’ with progress logging form

  • Redirects to ‘dashboard’ upon successful progress log

Return type:

HttpResponse

Raises:

Http404 – If the habit does not exist or does not belong to the user

Requires:

  • User authentication

Behaviors:

  • Checks for existing progress log on the same date

  • Updates existing log or creates a new log

  • Displays success message after logging progress

tracker.views.login_view(request)[source]

Handle user login authentication.

This view manages the login process for existing users. If the user is already authenticated, they are redirected to the dashboard. For POST requests, it validates credentials and logs in the user.

Parameters:

request (HttpRequest) – The HTTP request object.

Returns:

  • Renders ‘authentication/login.html’ with login form

  • Redirects to ‘dashboard’ upon successful authentication

Return type:

HttpResponse

Behaviors:

  • Redirects authenticated users to dashboard

  • Authenticates users with valid credentials

  • Displays error messages for invalid login attempts

tracker.views.logout_view(request)[source]

Handle user logout and session termination.

This view logs out the current user and redirects them to the home page. It also displays a farewell message with the user’s username.

Parameters:

request (HttpRequest) – The HTTP request object.

Returns:

Redirects to ‘home’ page after logging out the user.

Return type:

HttpResponse

Behaviors:

  • Terminates the current user’s session

  • Displays a logout confirmation message

tracker.views.register_view(request)[source]

Handle user registration for new accounts.

This view manages the user registration process. If the user is already authenticated, they are redirected to the dashboard. For POST requests, it validates the registration form and creates a new user account.

Parameters:

request (HttpRequest) – The HTTP request object.

Returns:

  • Renders ‘authentication/register.html’ with registration form

  • Redirects to ‘dashboard’ upon successful registration

Return type:

HttpResponse

Behaviors:

  • Redirects authenticated users to dashboard

  • Creates user account on valid form submission

  • Displays form errors on invalid input
